title: £2m tidal turbine providing energy spins in to action
story: A poundm tidal turbine currently in Strangford Lough could provide electricity for between - homes, it has been revealed.The Scottish firm behind the innovative Subhub has said that energy produced from the fast-flowing lough could cost as low as p per kWH for local industrial load customers.However, the Subhub is not connected to the local electricity grid and is being tested for its environmental impact and maintenance needs.The distinctive yellow Subhub mdash which is roughly the size of of a bus mdash has been in Castleward Bay for the last six weeks.Easily seen from Portaferry, it was towed from Belfast Harbour and fixed into position within  hours on January .Jeremy Smith, managing director of QED Naval, said that Strangford Lough was chosen over the Orkneys for the Subhubrsquos final commissioning before being made available for the global market.Mr Smith explained: ldquoThe Subhub is a foundation structure for tidal turbines and provides a means of transporting and fixing tidal turbines to the sea bed.ldquoWe want to prove the environmental credentials of Subhub after developing it since .ldquoWe selected Strangford Lough as the commissioning site specically as it had the iants of conditions that Orkney hadnrsquot. The Orkneys was problematic as itrsquos a long way away. It would also have costed a lot of money to tow up into position but also the conditions up there were not what was needed.ldquoOur Strangford site has fast-flowing water, a pure rock sea bed and is a stonersquos throw from the shoreline. Itrsquos very accessible and also happens to be a beautul part of the world.Mr Smith said that the Subhub would be in the lough for the next three months at least as it was being assessed.ldquoWe are working with Cuan Marine Services who provides us with daily reports really to see what the environmental impact is for marine mammals.He said that QED Naval had developed Subhub which was less expensive to make, to move into position and to decommission, than other tidal wave s.He believes that some industrial load customers could avail from its electricity.ldquoIndustrial load customers could be paying between -p per kWH now, added Mr Smith.ldquoIf we could work with local industrial customers to get power purchase agreements, there is potential for us to cut their fuel bills for heating water to less p per kWh.QED Naval has worked in collaboration with the Centre for Advanced Sustainability at Queenrsquos University on the project.The Subhub spent last year being equipped at Cimpina Engineering in Belfast before being moved to Strangford Lough.This is the second tidal power development in Strangford Lough.The worldrsquos first commercial-scale tidal turbine was commissioned on the lough in July, .The .MW SeaGen project developed by Marine Current Turbines comprised two KW turbines and represented a poundm investment. It has since been decommissioned..prettyPhoto

title: Celebration at Dromara for fanciers
story: DROMARA HPS recently held their annual dinner and prize distribution in the Pheasant Restaurant, Annahilt.Unfortunately, numbers were down a little this year with some members unable to attend due to health reasons and the club would like to wish Albert McKinstry and Harry Silcock speedy recoveries.Although some older members were missing, it was great to welcome two new members, Matthew Russell and Christopher Rooney who was accompanied by his we, Gail.After a beautul meal Mr and Mrs Rooney presented the prizes and cups. As everyone knows, Dromara is a strong club but this year surpassed all expectations with the club being the only one in Ireland to have its members win two INFC Nationals.N Black  Son won the Friendship National and N Edgar  Son won the Skibbereen National.The Edgar partnership had a fantastic young bird season as well, winning the NIPA Young Bird National from Rosscarbery.N Black  Son also won the NIPA section D Old Bird Channel fancier. Russell Brothers also had another great season winning the highly prized McBride Cup for the channel averages plus winning Penzance Classic.C  L Fryers had the first bird from Dromara in the Kingrsquos Cup. McKinstry Brothers had some great results along with T Marshall  Son, first bird in Penzance Young Bird, D McCandless Yearling National winner.Mr  Mrs Stevenson again did well inland as well as beating the big boys on the channel by winning first Tallbenny.H Silcock had some great positions and were unlucky to be fourth open Friendship National and still be only second in the club.After the prizes and trophies were handed out Mrs Rooney presented Fiona Stevenson with a bouquet of flowers mdash a small token of thanks for the hospitality from her and Bobby throughout the year.As usual, the highlight of the evening was the ballot and with Stanley McKinstry not attending this year his luck was taken up by Fiona Stevenson.In fact they won so many young birds Bobby thought he might not even have to breed any of his own. N Edgar  Son and N Black  Son kindly donated two young birds each.Edgarrsquos two were won by new member Chris Rooney and Mr  Mrs Stevenson and Blackrsquos two young birds were won by Gordon Kirkpatrick and Mr  Mrs Stevenson.C  l Fryersrsquo young bird was won by non-fancier William Skelly, who is putting it into the stable of N Black  Son to be raced.Cromie  Magee and Sonsrsquo was won by Russell Bros, Mr  Mrs Stevensonrsquos by Chris Rooney, Russell Bros by H Silcock, T Marshall  Sonrsquos by Mr  Mrs Stevenson and A Bradleyrsquos was won by P Connor..prettyPhoto

title: Conal Montgomery samples new sound
story: KILLYLEAGH rocker Conal Montgomery is working on new original music for the first time in years.The well-known singer who has performed at bikersrsquo rallies and conventions around the UK for the last  years may surprise some of his fans with his new sound.Instead of the soaring progressive rock vocals he is known for, Conalrsquos new music is softer, more reflective folk style.The  year-old says that his new music is indicative of where he is in his personal le now.The  year-old explained: ldquoI havenrsquot felt like this for years particularly as when I was drinking I really couldnrsquot be bothered with writing music.ldquoI wrote songs in the early s but alcohol and drugs just took over my le and my time was wasted.ldquoFor  odd years I didnrsquot do anything and now that Irsquom sober, I just have a love for it. I just want to try and put out what Irsquove been feeling for a long time.Conal first developed a love for music by listening to his big brotherrsquos Elvis Presley records.He later began to perform as the lead singer with the local band Bone Idle before moving on to Freak Out and then to Sweet Leaf mdash the band he fronted for  years.ldquoIrsquove been fronting rock bands for the last  years since my early twenties and it was always just covers like AC DC, Led Zeppelin and Lynyrd Skynyrd, Conal continued.ldquoBut when I started to write music, that wasnrsquot what was coming out of me. It was more singer songwriter, folky stuff.ldquoIt wasnrsquot really a surprise to me as the stuff I would have listened to outside my giging would have been the likes of Bob Dylan and Steve Earle.Conal is recording his new songs with the band Stillwater, which also features Killyleagh musician Damien Hanna.While he is experiencing a creative purple patch, the father-of-four does not yet know when the music will be available.ldquoI donrsquot have a title for my new EP yet as Irsquom still writing and Irsquom still recording. I would hope that the EP would be out by the summer and the album by the end of the year but you never know, the EP could turn into the album.He and Stillwater performed two of Conalrsquos new tracks, Venus and All of the People, in an interview on That Like That on NVTV.Conal says that the second track is really resonating with people.ldquoThis track is aimed at society in general, not only young people on Facebook, but all those who point the finger at somebody and gang up on some poor soul, he explained.ldquoThen when something happens to that poor soul, then yoursquoll get the smiley faces and comments of lsquoHe was a great fellarsquo or lsquoShe was a great girlrsquo and hopefully it teaches them a lesson to realise what people might be going through on the inside.Conal is a regular at Denvirrsquos in Downpatrick and will next perform with Stillwater in Portrush Town Hall at the North West  in MayTo watch Conalrsquos interview and performance on NVTVrsquos Talk Like That visit twww.nvtv shows talk-like-that-conal-montgomery Conal and Stillwater on their Facebook pages or ring Conal on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Ear%2C nose and throat to make way for new cataract surgery
story: PLANS for a specialist regional centre of excellence for cataract surgery at the Downe Hospital have come at a price.Health chiefs have confirmed this week that ear, nose and throat day surgery sessions currently provided in Downpatrick are relocating to Lisburnrsquos Lagan Valley Hospital to make way for the new cataract service which could be operational in the near future.While the South Eastern Trust has confirmed that ENT day surgery service is moving to Lisburn, the organisation is insisting there are no plans to reduce the number of ear, nose and throat clinics delivered at the Downe, with the current number set to increase.Last year, the Department of Health revealed that the Downpatrick hospital would be at the forefront of a new model of care with the Downe set to provide a new consultant-led, prototype cataract service for patients from across a wide area.The new service is designed to signicantly reduce surgery waiting lists, with the elective care centre providing routine day surgery procedures at an enhanced outpatient department at the Downe.The centre will be evaluated on performance, quality, service user and staff experience, productivity and overall value for money.While delighted with this, former South Down MP Margaret Ritchie is concerned that ENT day surgery is moving to Lisburnrsquos Lagan Valley and is arguing there is a need for the retention of this specialist service locally.ldquoThis particular service is well received and utilised in the Downe, said Miss Ritchie.As part of the regionalisation of clinics and services, the Downpatrick hospital will soon provide a regional opthalmology service which involves cataract surgery and is very welcome.ldquoAs part of this regionalisation of services, it is important that those services such as ENT surgical clinics, which have been in existence for some time, continue to remain in the hospital. In fact, the South Eastern Trust has been concentrating for some time on trying to find suitable day surgical services which could be delivered in Downpatrick.Miss Ritchie said it appears ldquovery short sighted to relocate services from the Downe to other hospitals, suggesting the bedding down of eye surgery will result in the increased requirement for theatre access for ENT and other services.She added: ldquoAs the Downe has high level computerised technology theatres, it is important that full use is made of them to ensure continued local accessibility to day surgery services at the point of delivery.ldquoI have already written to the Trust urging that ENT surgical clinics are retained in the Downe Hospital.Also this week, Miss Ritchie has issued a fresh call for a permanent MRI scanner to be installed in Downpatrick.She said that for a number of years the local community has been involved in trying to secure a permanent scanner which health chiefs agree is a necessity.She added: ldquoI understand that the permanent facility is subject to a business case which needs a Minister in place to approve. Whilst the devolved institutions remain in cold storage, the approval of such a facility will probably take some time.ldquoIn the meantime, a mobile scanner has been located at the Downe for a limited period to deal with a current overburdened service at the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald. I hope this unit can remain in place until the business case for the permanent scanner has been approved.A South Eastern Trust spokeswoman has confirmed that there are no plans to reduce the number of ENT sessions delivered at the Downpatrick hospital.She added: ldquoThe Trust is planning to increase ENT clinics at the Downe and to relocate an ENT day surgery session from Downpatrick to the Lagan Valley Hospital to facilitate the cataract elective care centre prototype work..prettyPhoto

title: Food firm to create 125 jobs with £17m investment
story: DOWNPATRICK is in line for a major jobs boost.Finnebrogue Artisan has this week unveiled plans to create  new jobs as part of a poundm investment in an ultra-modern nitrite-free bacon facility.The news comes just weeks after the firm unveiled details of a poundm investment in a new vegan and vegetarian factory to support  jobs.Already one of the districtrsquos leading employers and widely regarded as one of Northern Irelandrsquos most innovative food producers, Finnebrogue Artisanrsquos latest investment is being supported by Invest NI.The new manufacturing facility is for the production of the companyrsquos nitrite-free bacon, hailed by many experts as a breakthrough in the food processing sector when it was unveiled to wide acclaim in January last year.The Naked Bacon range is now widely available in leading supermarkets across the UK, with Invest NI offering the Downpatrick company over pound.m of support towards the capital investment in the new nitrate-free bacon facility.The  new posts are expected to be created by , supporting  posts already in place at the ultra-modern plant outside Downpatrick.Finnebrogue chairman Denis Lynn says it has been known for decades that nitrites used in curing meat can cause cancer.ldquoThatrsquos why, despite being the UKrsquos leading top tier sausage maker, we refused to make a single rasher of bacon until we could figure out a way to make it better and safer, he continued.ldquoWe always set out to make food the best it can be, without being bound by the way it has always been done. And so, after much research, we discovered a process that uses fruit and spice extracts to flavour the pork, keep it pink and retain shelf le.Mr Lynn added: ldquoWe are using this technology in our Naked Bacon and wersquove had a great response from both retailers and consumers.Invest NIrsquos executive director of business and sector development, Brian Dolaghan, said Northern Irelandrsquos reputation as a region that produced ldquoinnovative, quality food had been enhanced by the innovation and development of nitrite-free bacon by Finnebrogue.ldquoThe product has been welcomed by top food scientists as a signicant advancement in food safety and has already found a market among health conscious consumers, he continued.ldquoAgri-food is one of our priority sectors and it is great to see the new facility operational and producing this cutting-edge product. Our support is ensuring Finnebrogue is able to capitalise on its innovation and realise growth.Mr Dolaghan added: ldquoThe local economy will also benefit from this fantastic food innovation as the  new jobs will deliver over poundm to the economy each year in salaries.The Downpatrick firm also produces and sells The Good Little Company range of healthy sausages and recently opened a vegetarian factory producing innovative, meat-free meal options.Finnebrogue Artisan is regarded as one of the fastest growing food manufacturers in the UK with its turnover increasing from poundm to over poundm per year over the past ten years.The company says that following Invest NIrsquos support, it anticipates that sales of Naked Bacon will add poundm to its turnover by .Invest NI has offered Finnebrogue Artisan an employment grant of pound, and a capital grant of pound, to boost its latest investment programme..prettyPhoto

title: Football crazy siblings set to be future stars
story: A DOWNPATRICK brother and sister have the football world at their feet.Nine year-old Annie Montgomery and her  year-old brother Josh, are football crazy and both have been earmarked as stars of the future.Annie, a pupil at St Brigidrsquos Primary School, who plays for Rossglass County in the Downpatrick Youth Leaguersquos small sided games, has just been selected to take part in the IFArsquos Elite Girlsrsquo development programme.Not to be outdone, Josh, a pupil at De La Salle High School, who plays for Cltonville in the National League, has been selected for the Lisburn Youth League Select team to play in this yearrsquos prestigious Dublin Cup.Annie, a box-to-box midfielder, who has an eye for goals, started her career with Celtic Bhoys first kickers at age six, but she soon moved to Rossglass County, where her dad BJ played his football.ldquoShe really enjoys scoring goals and can play anywhere, said her father.ldquoAnnie was enjoying her time at Celtic Bhoys, but she moved to Rossglass to get more game time and hasnrsquot looked back. She spends hours out on the Red High pitch, which is just across the road and she and Josh just compliment each other.ldquoShe is a great wee worker, willing to learn the tricks of the trade and takes everything in her stride, he added.ldquoIdeally, Annie would drove to play in a girlsrsquo only side, but she knows how to mix it with the best come Sunday morning. She is in a mixed team and can handle herself.Josh, who also started out with Celtic Bhoys before moving to Downpatrick FC, was picked up by Solitude scouts after a series of trial games and he now attends training at the North Belfast club twice a week.ldquoHe has come on leaps and bounds since joining Cltonville, said his dad.ldquoHe has won the player of the year for the past two seasons in a row and just loves being part of the set-up at Cltonville. He also scores goals for fun, but doesnrsquot mind ping back a little to help out when his side lose possession, Mr Montgomery added.ldquoThe coaches at Cltonville have really helped him and he doesnrsquot mind the travelling up to Belfast three times a week. He would travel anywhere to get a game of football.Both Annie and Josh are fanatical Manchester United players and love nothing more than a trip to Old Trafford to see the Red Devils play.However, they have turned the football pitches at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School into their own theatre of dreams and the only way is up for the talented siblings..prettyPhoto

title: French journalists visit fantastique Thrones locations
story: FRENCH travel journalists and bloggers have visited popular beauty spots in Co Down connected with the blockbuster Game of Thrones TV series.Some of Francersquos top media writers, who have a combined following of over six million people, were invited by Tourism NI to spend a few days visiting Tollymore Forest, Inch Abbey and Castle Ward, among others, recently.The fantasy epic has gained a cult following around the world in recent years and some of the locations used in the shooting of the series include Castle Ward and the nearby Audleyrsquos Castle, which dates from the th century.The journalists also stopped off at Cushendun, the Dark Hedges, Dunluce Castle and the Giantrsquos Causeway.Monica MacLaverty, Tourism Ireland Manager said: ldquoThe eighth and final season of Game of Thrones will air this spring, so we are taking every opportunity to highlight Northern Ireland as the lsquoHome of Thronesrsquo to fans in France and where around the world.ldquoThe visit of these top French travel writers and bloggers is an excellent opportunity to showcase Northern Ireland to a wide audience of fans and holidaymakers.ldquoTheir articles, posts and photos will be seen and shared by their readers and online followers, inspiring them to come and explore Northern Ireland for themselves.She added: ldquoTourism Ireland undertakes a busy publicity programme around the world each year to raise the profile of Northern Ireland ndash and visits by journalists and social influencers are a key element of that programme.Game of Thrones fever is on the rise once again, with anticipation mounting among fans everywhere about the long-awaited final season, which is set to begin in April..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C February 27%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash The Department of the Environmentrsquos Roads Division warned yesterday that staff cutbacks could substantially delay two new major schemes in Downpatrick.Divisional Roads boss Mr J D Kirk admitted that several proposed schemes will be hit, including a car park in the Irish Street Market Street area of Downpatrick and a realignment programme for Saul Street and Scotch Street.Mr Kirk claims that he does not have a large enough supervisory staff to carry out work which has been programmed.Mr Kirk stressed that the cutbacks could not have come at a worse time when the Roads Service is under heavy pressure to complete schemes and also to start several others which are in the pipeline.He explained that the long-awaited new pound, car park for Downpatrick now seemed certain to run into further dficulties and that the realignment programme will suffer from the staff shortages.Downpatrick councillors have hit out at the threat of further delays to local schemes. Cllr George Flinn was particularly outraged. ldquoI am amazed to hear of this and deplore any delays in schemes that should have been completed a long time ago., he said.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Ballynahinch Chamber of Commerce are to continue their efforts to have the townrsquos police station opened full time.The Chamberrsquos executive committee, who met recently, discussed an acknowledgment from RUC headquarters, saying they would look at the possibility. The committee agreed to pursue the matter.At the same meeting members expressed pleasure at the announcement that the Department of the Environment intend spending pound, on improved lighting in the town, but they showed deep concern over the Department of Educationrsquos decision not to provide a swimming pool for the town.Already local schools are up in arms about the decision, as the pool would have provided swimming facilities for over , pupils. However, the Chamber intend to follow it up and are to invite representatives of the ious schools to meet them in April to discuss the situation.DRUMAGHLIS mdash The future of Drumaghlis Primary School is causing problems for the South Eastern Education and Library Board. The Department of Education havenrsquot yet disclosed their intentions, in spite of having been told of strong feeling that it should not be closed.Mrs Ethel Smyth, a member of the maintained schools committee, was irritated by the lack of information from the Department.She said the school had  pupils and assumed maintained status in January of last year. In June members of the committee requested financial help from the Department to modernise the toilets abed were concerned to receive a letter asking their views on the schoolrsquos future.Mrs Smyth said that parents of children attending the school were totally opposed to its closure in view of the long distances by the pupils would have to travel to other schools.KILLYLEAGH mdash An emergency meeting of Killyleagh Young Farmersrsquo Club was held in the townrsquos Masonic hall this week.Twenty-six people were present, including a representative from YFC headquarters. The meeting was chaired by Mr Denis McAuley, from Downpatrick YFC. A y and informative discussion took place during which many helpful points were raised regarding the future of the club.The election of the senior officials and office bearers was completed and all posts were filled. Finally, after the interest shown in the club at the emergency meeting, members stressed that the look forward to a very successful year.STRANGFORD mdash The Department of Environment has proposed that crossing fares for the Strangford ferry should be increased.Ards Borough councillors were told this week that the Downpatrick DoE office, which administers the ferry, has recommended that fees should be increased in line with the rising costs of operating the service.If a new increase is implemented, it will mean that a passenger will pay p to use the ferry between Strangford and Portaferry instead of the present rate of p. The new cost for a motorcycle will be p instead of p car fares will go up to p from p vehicles up to two tons will pay pound mdash an increase of p and vehicles up to five tons will pay pound instead of pound..A letter to the council said that the Department believed that it was better to introduce ldquomodest annual increases rather than larger ones every few years. Councillors decided to consider the matter fully and to write to the Department expressing their views.NEWCASTLE mdash Mr Dermot Patrick Herlighy , of Clontarf, Dublin, died suddenly at Royal County Down Golf Club on Saturday morning from a coronary attack.The deceased was a member of the Irish international golfing party who were practising on the course at the weekend.BALLYGOWAN mdash Residents in Ballygowan have called for the removal of a water booster generator near the town which has created a traffic hazard for more than a year.The problem relates to huge booster which was erected on a bend on the Carrickmannon Road to increase pressure in the water supply for parts of the area.Local councillor Jim McBriar says he wants the generator removed before it causes a serious accident.ldquoThis booster may be serving a need until a proper replacement is provided, but local people want it removed because it is hazardous, he said.A spokesman for the Water Service said they had very little power in the situation. ldquoWe asked the Northern Ireland Electricity Service some time ago to provide a temporary booster until the water situation was sorted out, he said.ldquoHowever, it has been there for more than  months now and it should it up to them to remove it.Initially, the generator was only meant to operate temporarily, but now local people fear that it may stay there indefinitely.KILLINCHY mdash Mr Tom Pendry, the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State in the Northern Ireland Office with responsibility for Agriculture, visited Cuan Sea Fisheries Ltd, near Killinchy, on Saturday.Dr Jasper Parsons, general manager of Cuan Sea Fisheries, met Mr Pendry, and led him on a conducted tour of the oyster farm.Cuan Sea Fisheries, which employs a staff of eight, was established six years ago on the shores of Strangford Lough. Pacic oysters, imported as seed from hatcheries in England, are reared in the lough on trays and in nets.Interest in oyster farming grew in Northern Ireland in  after successful experimental work by the Department of Agriculturersquos Fisheries Division which showed that the Pacic oyster could thrive in Strangford Lough.CARRYDUFF mdash Plans are being drawn up for a new pedestrian crossing scheme in Carryduff.Residents in the area have been pressing for a controlled crossing system with traffic lights for some time and at last it looks s through work is in the pipeline.Members of Castlereagh Borough Council heard that there are plans for crossings on the Ballynahinch Road, Church Street and the Hillsborough Road.BALLYKINLAR mdash Downpatrick firemen answered a call to a gorse fire at Ballykinlar Camp on Saturday. Approximately six acres of gorse had been extinguished on arrival.CASTLEWELLAN mdash The game fishing season begins shortly, but anglers wishing to use Castlewellan Lake will have to wait another month.Although the Department of Agriculture have  game and mixed fisheries to offer anglers, , including Castlewellan, will not open until April  to facilitate spring stocking.Already an experiment to test ious methods of stocking is being conducted in Castlewellan Lake. This involves the tagging of a large number of fish.SPA mdash A capacity audience filled Ballynahinch High Schoolrsquos assembly hall to see Spa Young Farmersrsquo Clubrsquos presentation of George Shielsrsquo evergreen comedy play, The New Gossoon.The cast did the author and themselves proud with their presentation. So well received was the play that inquiries are already being made with regard to taking it on a short local tour. The play was produced by Mr Cecil Orr, the club president..prettyPhoto

title: Gates swing open at new play parks
story: TWO childrenrsquos play parks were opened in Saintfield and Killyleagh last week.They are part of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Be Active campaign which was launched last year.The parks were part funded by the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership, which is supported by the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand the EU, with Newry, Mourne and Down Council contributing towardS the investment.Lislane play park in Saintfield was officially opened by council chairman Mark Murnin with support from pupils of Academy Primary School and St Maryrsquos Primary School in the town, who were involved in the consultation process.The children were delighted to try out the new equipment that ranges from zip lines to a rota-web climber and a hot shot target wall.The second play park to be opened was at the Bridge Centre in Killyleagh where Cllr Murnin was joined by children from Killyleagh Integrated Primary School and St Maryrsquos Primary School.The pupils enjoyed playing on the Rock lsquonrsquo Bowl, Double Zig-Zag Twister, and the Playtronic Daisy Chain Reactions game. They also enjoyed signing their names using the free standing lsquoSign Your Namersquo play .  Cllr Murnin said: ldquoI am delighted to officially open both play parks. These facilities will no doubt be incredibly beneficial to the members of the community, giving children a safe place to play. It also highlights the councilrsquos commitment in delivering on its play strategy and we will continue to improve play facilities throughout the district.ldquoThe play parks are fantastic assets to both Saintfield and Killyleagh and are already being well used by the children. It is great to see their communities working together.He added: ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down District strongly believe in the importance of play in a childrsquos physical and social development, and it is an integral part of growing up, we hope everyone enjoys using these facilities.The development of the play facilities will see children and young people across the district benefit from the latest state of the art equipment.Cllr Roisin Mulgrew, Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership chairperson, said: ldquoThis partnership project between Newry, Mourne and Down District Council, the Rural Development Partnership and our local rural communities is delivering real impact on the ground, producing state of the art play parks in many areas.lsquoOur children and young people are the ultimate winners who will benefit from these fantastic facilities.Jerome Burns, DAERA representative, added: ldquoThe Department is delighted to be a partner in this project which has produced such a signicant impact across the district.ldquoCouncil funding matched with EU funding through the Rural Development Fund has maximised the overall impact.ldquoThe positive benefits of play for children is matched by the positive impacts on the whole community including improved access to facilities, health and well-being and community cohesion..prettyPhoto

title: Lidl secures permission for new Newcastle store
story: SUPERMARKET giant Lidl is on the verge of securing outline planning permission for a major new store in Newcastle.Almost three years after it purchased the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site in the town, planners are recommending that the redevelopment proposal in an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty should proceed.Lidl submitted plans to redevelop the . acre Shanslieve Drive site in January last year, with the ambitious redevelopment including a new pound, base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team.The recommendation to grant outline planning approval for the brownfield site will be tabled at next weekrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee.Lidl Northern Irelandrsquos regional director, Conor Boyle, said the company welcomed the plannersrsquo approval recommendation for its proposed new store.Hs added: ldquoWe have engaged with the local community extensively on this proposal and look forward to the next stages in the planning process.Permission is being sought to bulldoze the existing school to pave the way for the construction of a new food store and dedicated centre for the volunteers who run the mountain rescue team.A new entrance via Bryansford Road is proposed, but there will be no access from Shanslieve Drive. The development proposal includes plans for almost  parking spaces, eight of which are reserved for mountain rescue team members.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal and while planners have received  objections, they have also received five letters in support of the proposal.In papers submitted ahead of next weekrsquos meeting, planners confirm that none of the statutory consultees, including the Department for Infrastructure, Rivers Agency, Environment Agency and the local environmental health department, have lodged any objections to the redevelopment of the former school site.They confirm that roads officials are content that the proposed development will not have any ldquoadverse impact on the existing road infrastructure and is acceptable in terms of road safety.Planners are also insisting that the indicative designs of both the new store and mountain rescue centre would not be inappropriate in this part of the resort.They say it is acknowledged that there are ldquoobvious restrictions for the redevelopment of the existing Lidl store in Railway Street and there are no alternative vacant sites in the town centre which can accommodate the supermarketrsquos needs.ldquoA suitable brownfield site has become available at the edge of the town centre which could accommodate the proposal and has met the requirements of strategic planning policy, say planners.They also confirmed that a study of the impact of the new store on existing retailers shows the proposed investment will not have any ldquosignicant or unacceptable impact on Newcastle town centre.Environmental health officials say they have no objection in principle to the investment, provided conditions are attached restricting hours of business and deliveries, with planners concluding that the overall impact of the proposal, which is close to a number of homes, is not considered to be ldquosignicantly detrimental to warrant a refusal of the application.Lidl has confirmed it plans to develop a new , square metre supermarket, explaining it opted to redevelop the former primary school site as there are limited opportunities to redevelop the storersquos current base at Railway Street in the resort.Lidl says it has been looking for alternative premises in Newcastle town centre for over a decade without success and that while properties have become available, none were suitable because they were too small.It says the current sales area at its Railway Street base is is too small for the store to carry a full range of goods, pointing to narrow aisles with limited circulation space. The company says the car park is too small and fails to meet its requirements, with the general customer experience falling short of a modern food store.Planners say that having assessed the ious planning policies and having regard to all representations made, all consultees engaged and all other material considerations, it is found that the proposal is acceptable in planning terms and approval is recommended..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle’s pop up beach back on agenda of council
story: A DECISION to reject a proposal for a pop-up beach in Newcastle has been overturned.Last month, a Newry, Mourne and Down Council Committee recommended not to proceed with the articial beach mdash similar to those in Paris and other parts of Europe ndash at the townrsquos promenade.However, the decision was overturned at Monday nightrsquos meeting of the full council when it was agreed to seek funding for the pop-up beach and develop a business case which could pave the way for its introduction.But not all councillors agreed, with Sinn Fein members rejecting it. They said there were health and safety concerns associated with the beach. They expressed support for transporting sand by road from Ballykinlar to Newcastle promenade and implementing an enhanced beach management plan.The radical suggestion to bring a touch of French summer flair to Newcastle was initially discussed last September when it was agreed to further explore the idea, with the initial focus on the cost of developing such a facility.The idea was suggested because of the lack of sand on Newcastle beach.Pop up beaches along the banks of the Seine and other cities and towns across Europe are hugely popular and some local politicians believe they can be a success in Newcastle.Council officials have confirmed that while Newcastle promenade is not suitable for pop-up beaches, two areas adjacent to the Downs Road car park would be suitable and that the cost over a nine-week period would be pound,.At last monthrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee, politicians rejected the pop-up proposal and agreed to seek a meeting with the Environment Agency to discuss securing a marine licence to transport sand from Ballykinlar to Newcastle.It was also suggested that groins would be placed along sections of beach to protect the sand and a programme of better beach management introduced. On Monday night, this recommendation was overturned by  votes to .Mournes SDLP councillor Laura Devlin, who initially proposed to explore the merits of a pop-up beach, said the local authority ldquoneeds to think outside the box to create an articial beach or ldquosimply accept that Newcastle will never have a sandy beach.She continued: ldquoIf improving the natural beach was an option I would obviously proceed in that direction. However, it is not workable.ldquoI have been advised in no uncertain terms by a iety of coastal erosion experts that importing sand to Newcastle or removing stones from the beach simply wonrsquot work due to the movement of sediment and that permission to do this work would be denied by central government.ldquoAs a councillor for Newcastle, I want to improve our tourism product and the pop-up beach proposal is simply my suggestion to try and do something dferent. I also recognise that an articial beach would have to be properly managed and maintained.Cllr Devlin added: ldquoA pop-up beach could not just be created at the start of the summer and left. It would have to be adequately cleaned and looked after. As a mother, I would not want my child playing in dirty sand so the management and cleanliness of the pop up beach is essential.ldquoThis suggestion wonrsquot be without itrsquos issues, but surely as a council it is our job to try and make improvements and better our area where possible, expressing disappointment Sinn Fein opposed her proposal.Sinn Feinrsquos Willie Clarke argued that there was no appetite for a pop-up beach and that the suggestion to move sand from Ballykinlar to Newcastle was to replace the hundreds of tonnes which drt away on a seasonal basis.He continued: ldquoHow are you going to manage a pop-up beach that will be filled with stagnant sand  There is the potential for both dogs and young infants to foul the sand and other health and safety issues which need to be addressed.ldquoWill the sand be cleaned every day  What measures will be taken to prevent sand from blowing up Main Street  Local people and traders want to see a sandy beach, not a pop-up beach. I believe it is a no brainer that we try to secure Environment Agency agreement to place sand on the beach.Cllr Clarke said part of the pleasure of going to the beach was being able to go into the water and suggested that a pop-up beach could not provide such an experience.He added: ldquoWe need to look at anti-social behaviour issues associated with pop-up beaches which could contain broken glass. I wonder who is going to look after them given the dficulty I have in getting someone to clean the beach ldquoWe need to invest resources to ensure the proper management of the beach and encourage people to go to parts of it where there is sand.Cllr Andy McMurray described pursuing the idea as ldquofolly given the current problems in keeping the promenade tidy..prettyPhoto

title: O’Hare hat trick secures victory
story: A SUBLIME Donal OrsquoHare hat-trick at Glennon Brothers Peare Park, Longford, on Sunday reignited Downrsquos promotion aspirations.The Burren assassin was in a class of his own against the league leaders, but it also took some heroic goalkeeping from Castlewellanrsquos Rory Burns to keep Down on track for their third win on the bounce.Burns, who plays in midfield for his club, was inspirational between the sticks and in addition to keeping out another penalty mdash his second in three games mdash he produced several outstanding saves to deny Longford a goal they craved. Longford settled first and leading marksman Darren Gallagher registered the first score with a free in the fourth minute, but despite a lot of possession, the home side struggled to get scores on the board.Downrsquos defensive cover was superb with Saulrsquos Pierce Laverty making a more than impressive debut at half back.He received great support from Downpatrickrsquos Gerard Collins, Castlewellanrsquos Colm Flanagan and Bryansfordrsquos Ruairi Wells as Down closed up shop.Mind you, Down also struggled early on to get scores, but all that changed in the th minute.A measured long ball in from Caolan Mooney was ruthlessly pounced upon by OrsquoHare and he finished to the net with panache.Points from Gallagherand Liam Connerton drew Longford level in the th minute, but Down responded in style and regained the initiative with unanswered points from OrsquoHare , Conor Poland and corner back Gerard Collins.Longford had a goal chance in the th minute when Darren Quinn carved out an opening for the lurking Gallagher, but Burns made am outstanding save to deny the danger man and send Down in at the break with a - to - lead.Paddy Tallyrsquos men stretched their lead to seven within one minute of the second half when another long ball in, this time from Poland, picked out OrsquoHare and he grabbed his and his sidersquos second goal.Longford got a much needed point from Connor Berry in the th minute, but minutes later Burns denied Gallagher. Longford were made to rue those missed goal chances in the th minute when Jerome Johnston found Daniel Guinness and he played it to OrsquoHare who got his third goal.Berry kicked over a free in the th minute and two minutes later Longford had a chance for a goal when they were awarded a penalty after Quinn was fouled. Up stepped Gallagher, but his spot-kick was pushed out for a rsquo by the brilliant Burns. Gallagher made no mistake with the rsquo, but Longford really needed a goal at this stage.Jerome Johnstonand Daniel Guinness added points to their score while Longford got consolation points from Gallagher and Connerton.Down are now level on points with Louth, but behind on score dference. They have a chance to reduce that gap when they entertain Offaly at Pairc Esler on Saturday night.Down: R Burns, G Collins , R Wells, R McAleenan, P Laverty, C Flanagan, D OrsquoHagan, J Flynn, C Mooney, R Johnston, C Poland , C McGrady, D OrsquoHare , C Harrison, K McKernan. Subs: D Guinnessfor McGrady, B OrsquoHagan for Johnston, C Maginn for Flynn, J Johnstonfor Harrison, B McArdle for R Wells.Longford: P Collum, D Quinn, A Farrell, B OrsquoFarrell, CP Smyth, B McKeon, D Mimnagh, D Gallagher , M Quinn, S Donohoe, P Hanley, P Lynn, D Doherty, L Connerton , M Hughes. Subs: D McElligott for Donohoe, C Berryfor Hanley, Hagan for Lynn, J McGivney for Hughes, P Fox for Mimnagh..prettyPhoto

title: Planners give go ahead to Downpatrick hotel plans
story: DOWNPATRICK is in line for a major new -bedroom hotel.Planners will next week recommend that the eagerly-anticipated development on the site of the former Abbey Lodge Hotel on the Belfast Road should proceed.The new three storey hotel mdash being developed by Inch Abbey Holdings Ltd ndash features a range of leisure facilities including a swimming pool and health spa.The recommendation to approve the major new investment, which will create a number of full and part-time jobs, will be tabled at a meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee next Wednesday.In addition to the swimming pool and health spa, the new hotel will also offer bar, restaurant and conference facilities, asuite, changing rooms, treatment rooms, fitness suite and a gymnasium.Nine years ago, a property developer came close to investing in a new -bedroom hotel on the same site. While planning permission was secured, the proposal fell through due to the adverse economic circumstances at the town.The site was subsequently sold several years ago to a local businessman who is behind the new proposal to redevelop site which has been approved by a range of statutory agencies.Itrsquos understood access to the proposed new hotel will be via Inch Abbey Road, with parking located to the side and rear of the new , square metre building. There will also be a dedicated parking area for coaches.Original plans for the new hotel described finishing the exterior of the building in stone slate, with the accommodation centred around a landscaped courtyard. The proposed hotel development also includes plans to upgrade the Inch Abbey Road junction with the Belfast Road.News that the exciting new proposal is set to be given the green light next week comes after recent confirmation that planning permission is being sought to provide  new hotel rooms in Downpatrick town centre.The Downpatrick Property Trust is aiming to convert a number of existing flats at the junction of Market Street and Irish Street to provide what is being described as ldquooverflow hotel bedroom accommodation for nearby Denvirrsquos Coaching Inn.The proposal is also seeking permission for several hotel serviced apartments and to convert existing ground floor retail accommodation in Irish Street to a wheelchair accessible bedroom with an en-suite shower and toilet.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has placed tourism at the top of its agenda and is striving to attract more international visitors to stay overnight across the district. It has highlighted the need for additional hotel accommodation across the district.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran hopes the plannersrsquo recommendation for the Belfast Road site will be approved next week, paving the way for what he described as an ldquoexciting new development to help increase visitor number, provide new jobs and boost the local economy.He said the project would create jobs in the construction industry, provide a boost for local buildersrsquo suppliers and act as a catalyst for additional private sector investment.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThere is a need for more bed space in Downpatrick and this new development, which will complement existing provision, is most welcome. The fact that new conference facilities form part of the new hotel proposal is an added boost to the town.ldquoThe new hotel will help the local council with its drive to attract more overnight visitors to the district and I very much look forward to construction work getting underway..prettyPhoto

title: Saints lose to league leaders
story: SAINTFIELD United hosted league leaders Aquinas in a much-anticipated clash of two of the top teams in the league.It was the visitors who drew first blood when the first corner of the game was kept alive at the back post and struck into the net to make the score -.The Saints tried to get their passing going, but were snuffed out by their opponents who didnrsquot want to allow the hosts to settle.They continued to cause trouble from set-pieces and Saintfield paid the price when once again a free kick was kept alive and the visitors were first to the second ball to make the score -.Saintfield now faced a great uphill battle, they kept trying to play their football, but chances were few and far between for both sides.Saintfield came out fast in the second half, looking to put their opponents onto the back foot and get back into the game.They thought they had when some good play down the right led to a shot from Adam Childs that hit the underside of the bar and appeared to cross the line, but not in the eyes of the referee who ruled against the hosts and the scoreline stayed -.The game was even throughout, the only other noteworthy chance falling to James Sofley who couldnrsquot find a way past the Aquinas lsquokeeper.The Saints will be looking to bounce back and get their revenge when they travel to Rathmore to face the same opponents this weekend..prettyPhoto

title: Sally Ann is spot on
story: FORTY years of patient waiting ended for Spa member Sally Ann Douglas last week when she recorded her first hole-in-one of her golfing career.The clubrsquos former lady captain hit the perfect shot at the par three eight hole in a game partnered by Joe and Marlene Crawford.ldquoI used a pitching wedge and Marlene and I watched it all the way until it landed in the cup, she said. ldquoI just thought, brilliant. At long last.But golf is in Sally Annrsquos blood. Her -year old mother, Dorothy Walsh, is still playing on a regular basis at her home club at Rathfarnham, Dublin, having taken up the game  years ago.Spa ladies will recall how Dorothy was guest of honour at Sally Annrsquos Lady Captainrsquos Day in  where she charmed everyone with her friendly personality and good humour..prettyPhoto

title: Success for Down GAA at anniversary Scór
story: DOWN GAA did the th anniversary of Scoacuter proud at the weekend.The format and competitions may have changed and evolved over the years, but the enthusiasm for the preservation of Irish cultural heritage has certainly not waned.On Friday night the crowd in St Michaelrsquos Hall, Finnis, for the East Down finals may have been small, but they were treated to high class entertainment in the solo singing, recitation, ballad group and leiacuteruiacute statisecategories with the winner and runner-up in each going through to the county finals.At the South Down finals in Mayobridge Community Centre on Saturday night the packed house was treated to an extraordinary bill of fare reminiscent of days gone by.The adjudicators in both isional finals had very tough jobs on their hands and it is unfortunate that some competitors had to miss out on the opportunity to compete in the county finals, which take place in St Patrickrsquos College, Scarva Banbridge, this Friday at .pm.Those taking part will be as follows:Ceili dancing mdash Cumann Pheadar Naofa Football, Cumann Pheadar Naofa Hurling, Mayobridge, Clann na Banna and Clonduff.Solo singing mdash Holly McKay , Seamus Gartland , Vivienne Murphyand Eimear Magee .Recitation mdash Sharlene Neeson , Kathleen Lucas , Clare McCartanand Donna Feeney .Ballad Group ndash Dundrum, Bryansford, Mayobridge and Cumann Pheadar NaofaLeiacuteruiacute Statise mdashDarragh Cross, Drumaness, Atticall and Rostrevor.Instrumental music mdash Clonduff, Cumann Pheadar Naofa and Mayobridge.Set dancing mdash Clonduff, Cumann Pheadar Naofa Football and Cumann Pheadar Naofa Hurling.With almost a full complement of competitors in each discipline taking part in the County Finals anticipation is already running at fever pitch.Down GAA Scor Committee wishes to clubs for hosting the competitions and everyone who contributed towards ensuring that they ran successfully.St Patrickrsquoc College, Banbridge, will also be the venue for an Ulster semi-final on Sunday, March .The county table quiz will take place in Burren on Friday, March , starting at pm. It only takes a maximum of four people to enter a team and it is hoped that clubs who were unable to field competitors in the lsquostage-basedrsquo competitions will enter a team. The winners goes directly through to the All-Ireland finals in Castlebar on Saturday, April ..prettyPhoto

title: outstanding quality at second calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. The Ulster Farmersrsquo Union also used the opportunity to discuss the implications for local farmers post Brexit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ruas winter fair to become important dairy showcase
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valMatthewClarke, who was a well-known and respected member of the community in Armagh and Richhill, was a prominent member of the Orange Institution and other loyal orders.Born on St Matthew’s Day, September , , he was one of six children of Matthew and Maud Clarke, of Fruitfield, Richhill. His sister Eva is the last survivor of that family unit.Educated at the Hardy Memorial School, Matthew left at the age of  to join the Bairnswear Company at their factory on the Loughgall Road in Armagh. There, he proved to be a dedicated, hardworking employee, and he stayed with the firm for the whole of his working le.In the course of his employment he worked his way through the ranks, to become the engineer in Armagh, and when the factory closed there, being transferred to Scotland for two years and England for another  until his retirement.Bairnswear also introduced him to his future we, Doreen, who worked in the clerical department: the couple were married in Lislooney Presbyterian Church, and celebrated  years of marriage last summer.The couple had two children, Colin and Neil, and the family grew again with Colin’s marriage to Orla and Neil’s marriage to Nichola - and then the arrival of the apple of Matthew’s eye, his granddaughter Grace.Matt Clarke had many interests, mourners heard at his funeral service in St Matthew’s Church in Richhill. Rev Gary McMurray told the congregation that his chief interest had probably been his garden, which was always immaculate, the result of hours outside working on his plants, and working in his greenhouse.“While Matthew enjoyed gardening, and growing things, perhaps his greatest pleasure was in sharing his produce with everyone - tomatoes and cucumbers chrysanthemums to brighten the homes of family and friends in winter cooking apples for tarts and crumbles at Hallowe’en his generosity and thoughtfulness was always evident, especially at Christmas,” he said.A dedicated member of the loyal orders, Matt Clarke was a member of Ballyleaney Purple Star LOL No , in which he had served as Worshipful Master, and District Master of Richhill, as well as serving on the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland.He joined the lodge in the early s and served as WM between  and , and a lodge spokesman said he would be greatly missed by the brethren.“He was a great man. He involved himself in everything to do with our lodge, even attended the five-a-side football tournaments which we have won seven out of the last  years, pool competitions and so on. He was an ever-present at the hall and will be sorely missed,” he said, adding: “Matt was a faithful and loyal Orangeman and he will be sorely missed by all within the Orange family.”In addition to serving as District Master of Richhill District LOL No , he was also a committee member of the Sir William Allen Fund, and as a member of the Grand Orange Lodge he worked on a number of committees. As a member of Grand Lodge he also worked on a number of committees, principally relating to Orange Hall and Orange Arch Insurance.Man remanded on murder charge over death of Belfast Community worker Ian Ogle Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"A keen lodge historian, he was instrumental in preserving one of the oldest private lodge minute books in existence his lodge, Ballyleaney Purple Star LOL No , found all their lodge minute books dating back to . In co-operation with the Grand Lodge, the oldest minute book was digitised and copies lodged with both Schomberg House and Sloan’s House Orange museums. Mr Clarke was also a member of the Royal Black Institution and the Apprentice Boys of Derry. He was a lelong member of St Matthew’s Church in Richhill. Interested in motorsports, he was an avid follower of Formula One on television and also attended the North-West  races each year.Despite his many interests, he was never happier than when he was spending time with his family, whether it was enjoying a takeaway at home or a holiday abroad.Following his retirement, Matt Clarke began to struggle with poor health in ious ways, but he was always brave, never complained, and did not let his challenges hold him back, still wanting to get up and out when he could.His family will remember him as someone who was at the very heart of the family and who loved having something to work on as well as enjoying a laugh and keeping up with all that was happening.His family thanked all the medical staff who cared for him at home, and also the staff in the Renal Unit at Daisy Hill Hospital in Newry. Thanks were also expressed for all those who came to the funeral to pay their respects.Following the funeral service, interment took place at Kilmore Parish Churchyard. Donations in lieu of flowers were encouraged to Kidney Care UK NI, made payable to Jackson Stoops  Sons, Funeral Directors,  Moy Road, Armagh BT DL.Mr Clarke is survived by his we Doreen, sons Colin title: pier  to re open under new company
story: Pier  Limited ceased trading on January  this year after Cardf insolvency firm Begbies Traynor confirmed it was going into liquidation.However, Stephen Jones, who owns company Sansemea Limited, has taken over the restaurant and said "nothing is changing" with how it operates.The company also bought the name Pier  and have retained original staff members and chefs.Mr Jones also said that all customers who booked at the restaurant or bought gt vouchers before Pier  Limited closed will be honoured by the new restaurant."The restaurant was in need of refurbishment," said Mr Jones. "It was struggling because all of the equipment was  years old so everything was obsolete."I decided to give it a go and take it over and bought Pier . We took it over on January  and needed an interim period where a lot of money and work was put into the refurbishment."We held interviews with the former staff and we have most of them working here again now. We also have three of five chefs that were at the restaurant previously, including a top chef who has worked in some of the best restaurants in the world."Mr Jones said the restaurant will retain certain features, and the new menu will have some classic dishes that have been the most popular at the venue. He said all the work put into renovating the kitchen, honouring customers and other bits of work has cost around pound, altogether, but believes Pier  is worth it."I have been eating at Pier  myself for  years before this investment," Mr Jones said. "They say in the business not to buy into what you like but there you go."Nothing is changing much here and it will continue to be the premier restaurant in the town and in the Vale." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff bus announces ticket price changes
story: For passengers travelling to the city, revised fares will mean an adult single ticket will increase from pound. to pound in Cardf.And an adult Day to Go ticket, which provides unlimited travel throughout Cardf, Penarth, Llandough and Dinas Powys, bought through the companyrsquos mobile app or website will be pound. or poundbought on the bus at the time of travel.Customers using the companyrsquos mobile app can bulk buy single trips for use in the city for the equivalent of pound. a journey.For younger travellers, the youth single remains unchanged at pound., while a youth Day to Go ticket will rise from pound. to pound..This is the first time the company has increased prices in  months.Cardf Bus managing director Cynthia Ogbonna said: ldquoWe are hugely proud of the fact that a Cardf Bus ticket is a passport to all parts of Cardf and beyond, not just a few select routes.ldquoWe have been getting people around this city for over  years. Our fares compare favourably to all other providers of comprehensive bus services."There are many ways to pay for your Cardf Bus ticket, you can pay on the bus in cash or by contactless or you can use the Cardf Bus app and pay for your tickets on your phone.ldquoCardf Bus is continuing to be the most viable alternative to commuting by car for most residents and these changes are about ensuring that we offer the most comprehensive network as possible. Residents need a bus company that covers the whole city and we are that company.The price change will come into effect in February. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: prime minister theresa may set to return to brussels

"   typemchtype" Skip to next image raquo s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHERESA May is to go back to the EU to try to renegotiate her Brexit deal after MPs gave their backing to proposals to replace the controversial backstop.But she earned an immediate rebuff from Brussels, where European Council president Donald Tusk insisted that the Withdrawal Agreement struck last November was not open for renegotiation.Meanwhile, one of Mrs Mays strongest negotiating weapons was ripped from her hands by MPs who voted to block a no-deal Brexit.In a night of high drama at Westminster, the Commons voted by  to  in favour of a proposal backed by the prime minister to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement and replace the backstop with "alternative arrangements" to avoid a hard border in Ireland.Mrs May said that the result showed there was a means of securing a "substantial and sustainable majority in this House for leaving the EU with a deal" and vowed to seek a new agreement with Brussels.But in a statement, Mr Tusks spokesman said: "The Withdrawal Agreement is and remains the best and only way to ensure an orderly withdrawal of the UK from the European Union. The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."And French President Emmanuel Macron also said the agreement was "not re-negotiable", in comments just moments before MPs voted.The Commons approved a cross-party amendment, tabled by Midlands MPs Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, rejecting a no-deal Brexit by  to .The vote is not legally binding on the government but will impose massive political pressure on the prime minister to delay Brexit from its scheduled date of March she cannot secure a new deal from Brussels.The PM told MPs: "I agree that we should not leave without a deal. However, simply opposing no-deal is not enough to stop it."The Government will now redouble its efforts to get a deal that this House can support."There was uproar in the chamber as she said: "There is limited appetite for such a change in the EU and negotiating it will not be easy. But in contrast to a fortnight ago, this House has made it clear what it needs to approve a withdrawal agreement."Mrs May said she would seek "legally binding changes to the Withdrawal Agreement that deal with concerns on the backstop while guaranteeing noto a hard border". article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Since this time the housing association has been working with local residents, the council and community organisations to alter the proposal to fit local need.The development, which was approved by the Vale of Glamorgan Council in April , will provide affordable homes. A local lettings policy will be in place, prioritising homes to people working and currently living in the area. The apartments will be available to let in Spring .The  square meter community facility, available in spring , will offer two multipurpose halls, offices and a new kitchen area to a charity or not for profit business with an interest in providing key activities to local people.Paul Roberts, chief executive of Newydd said: ldquoWe want this development to make a positive contribution to the community. title: huge education revamp in wales revealed
story: The new Welsh curriculum has been in development for a number of years, and now details of the changes the Welsh Government is proposing to make have been revealed.Among them are for traditional subject boundaries to be eliminated and replaced with a series of lsquoAreas of Learning and Experiencersquo, or AOLEs, covering the humanities, health and wellbeing, science and technology, languages, literacy and communications, expressive arts, and maths.Schools will continue to be required by law to teach both English and Welsh, along with religious studies and relationships and sexuality education, while literacy, numeracy and digital competence will be required for pupils aged up to .But religious studies will be revamped to include non-religious world views such as humanism and, as announced earlier this month, Welsh will no longer be classed as a second language, but placed on an equal footing with English.Meanwhile, the current key stages will be scrapped and replaced with lsquoprogression stepsrsquo measured at ages five, eight, ,  and , with assessment based on an inidual pupilrsquos progression, taking their own circumstances into account.The Welsh Government has said the proposals represent ldquothe biggest shake-up of Walesrsquo curriculum since the s.Education minister Kirsty Williams said: ldquoWe want a curriculum that focuses also on equality as well as quality to ensure our young people leave school as confident iniduals, empathetic iniduals and ready to play a full le in the world of work, in the world of Wales ndash indeed, as citizens of the world.Ms Williams added the new curriculum, which is being developed alongside teachers from across Wales, will come into force for primary schools and year seven pupils in September , meaning it will be fully rolled out across all year groups by . title: penarth hockey club adds pakistan international for promotion push
story: The clubrsquos st XI currently sits fourth overall in the Verde Recreo Premiership, but hopes that the addition of the highly-rated -year old will help to propel it into contention for promotion over the remainder of the season.Pakistanrsquos decision not to contest this yearrsquos inaugural FIH Pro League opened the door for Penarth to entice Ali to South Wales, and the former junior international will bring a wealth of experience to bear on the second half of the Premiership campaign.Despite playing in defence, Alirsquos  goals in  games have made him a vital part of Pakistanrsquos senior side, and his fearsome penalty corner drag flick should make him an equally-valued weapon for a Penarth side that has already enjoyed three promotions in as many seasons to reach the top flight of regional hockey.A medal-winner in junior international competitions, Ali has also tasted success in the prestigious Sultan Johor Cup, and represented his country at the Menrsquos Hockey World Cup, Asian Champions Trophy, Menrsquos Champions Trophy, Commonwealth Games and Asian Games, scoring five goals in seven games at the latter tournament in Indonesia last year.ldquoPenarth Hockey Clubrsquos ambition, record and playing style have helped to attract high-profile players in recent seasons, but nothing quite as big as this, player-coach Ben Croxall admitted.ldquoMubasharrsquos international experience will not only boost the squad, but his arrival should also provide us with another goal-scoring threat as we look to continue our climb up the Premiership standings and, hopefully, into contention for promotion at the end of the season.Ali is scheduled to make his Penarth debut in this weekrsquos trip to second-placed Cheltenham , as all five of the clubrsquos senior teamsto action after last weekendrsquos weather-enforced hiatus. title: penarths plans for an end of winter carnival in march pick up pace
story: Organisers are encouraging as many groups as possible to help prepare for the carnival-style celebration in Penarth of March  to March .The Vale brewery Tomos and Lilford have pledged to produce a special beer called called ldquoCarnival - Penarth Pale Ale.Rob Lilford, who runs the brewery with Rolant Tomos, said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be making this special carnival ale for the forthcoming Penarth Winter Carnival. Every beer should tell a story, and the carnival is a great initiative.As well as its own the beer, the two Penarth butchers, Thompson Family Butchers and David Lush Butchers, have both promised to produce special Penarth carnival sausages.There will be plenty of treats for Pancake night too. Penarth Pier Pavilion is open for youngsters on Pancake Tuesday, March  for a special pancake event with support from the Waterloo Tea Rooms, while the Italian Cultural Centre Wales will be teaching children about Italian carnival traditions.There will be plenty of music to accompany the feasting, with -man strong Welsh festival band Wonderbrass playing ious events across the town over the festival, finishing with a full band performance on March . Wonderbrass are known for their electric blend of New Orleans jazz, ska, and blues with contemporary hip-hop and funk updates.Those preferring their music a touch more traditional may prefer to sing with the Male Welsh Voice Choir, or the Criw Canu womenrsquos singing group. Both organisations will be holding open practice sessions ahead of time.Colourful carnival ribbon produced in Pembrokeshire will also be available for decorations and discounts. Perfect for colourful bunting, and many shops say festival-goers wearing the fabric will be in for special offers and discounts.The festival will open with long-distance cyclist Dave Hann.
